Based on the data in the table, what can be concluded about the solubility of <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The solubility of <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is unaffected by <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a constant value at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The solubility of <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is unaffected by <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because it is the same value for <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 7.00 and <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 8.00.

<math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is more soluble at higher <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because lower concentrations of <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math> shift the solubility equilibrium toward <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math> and <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math>.

<math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less soluble at higher <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because higher concentrations of <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math> shift the solubility equilibrium toward solid <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less soluble at higher <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because higher concentrations of <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math> shift the solubility equilibrium toward solid <math alttext="A g O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
